Sequence Information.Peptide Name: CF-14 (natural AMPs; catfish, fish, animals, XXA, UCLL1a; BBMm; BBN)

Literature Information.Literature: Sequence analysis: APD analysis reveals that the sequence of the peptide shows 40% similarity toPeptide 3967. GRAVY=0.6; Mol Mass. 1650.04.Activity: Broth microdilution: Active against S. aureus, Gram- S. putrefaciens (MIC 62.5 ug/ml), and E. coli.Peptide stability: cleaved by proteases trypsin, pepsin and proteinase K; retained activity pH 4-12, but reduced slightly at pH 2-3; stable at 40, 60, and 80oC, but activity started to reduce at 100oC.Toxicity: sheep RBC: poorly hemo.lytic at 500 ug/ml.Structure: Helical in 2.5% SDS. A proline is located in the middle of the sequence. This is similar to cell penetrating peptide buforin.MOA:bacteria: peptide treatment of S. putrefaciens led to total nucleotide leakage, suggesting pore formation. SEM showed a change in bacterial morphology. The peptide also binds to bacterial genomic DNA at 5 uM or greater. All in the well at high peptide concentrations.Updated 7/2021
Literature Information.Author: Li T, Liu Q, Wang D, Li J.2019
Literature Information.Reference: Fish Shellfish Immunol. 2019 Jul 7. pii: S1050-4648(19)30724-7. doi: 10.1016/j.fsi.2019.07.015.PubMed
Literature Information.Title: Characterization and antimicrobial mechanism of CF-14, a new antimicrobial peptide from the epidermal mucus of catfish
